titleStmt.title: Robust Adaptive Fuzzy Tracking Control for Pure-Feedback Stochastic Nonlinear Systems With Input Constraints

analytic.title: Robust Adaptive Fuzzy Tracking Control for Pure-Feedback Stochastic Nonlinear Systems With Input Constraints

biblStruct.note: received June 22, 2012; revised October 11, 2012; accepted January 8, 2012.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper is concerned with the problem of adaptive fuzzy tracking control for a class of pure-feedback stochastic nonlinear systems with input saturation. To overcome the design difficulty from nondifferential saturation nonlinearity, a smooth nonlinear function of the control input signal is first introduced to approximate the saturation function; then, an adaptive fuzzy tracking controller based on the mean-value theorem is constructed by using backstepping technique. The proposed adaptive fuzzy controller guarantees that all signals in the closed-loop system are bounded in probability and the system output eventually converges to a small neighborhood of the desired reference signal in the sense of mean quartic value. Simulation results further illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N the past several decades, backstepping-based adaptive control technique has become one of the most popular control approaches for a class of deterministic strict-feedback nonlinear systems, and some significant control schemes have been developed (see, for instance, [1]- [10] and the references therein). Since stochastic models play an important role in many branches of science and engineering applications, numerous control approaches for stochastic nonlinear systems have been developed to guarantee stability in probability. In particular, some results on backstepping technique developed for deterministic nonlinear strict-feedback systems have been successfully extended to stochastic nonlinear systems [11]- [24] For example, Pan and Basar [11] first solved the stabilization problem for stochastic nonlinear strict-feedback sys-tems by using a risk-sensitive cost criterion and a quadratic Lyapunov function, and the result guarantees global asymptotic stability in probability. Alternatively, by using a quartic Lyapunov function, Deng et al. [12]- [14] proposed a backstepping design for stochastic nonlinear strict-feedback and outputfeedback systems. Furthermore, in-depth study on adaptive control of stochastic nonlinear systems based on the quartic Lyapunov function was presented in [16]- [24]. Recently, an approximation-based adaptive control approach for stochastic nonlinear systems has been paid considerable attention, and some interesting results were reported [25]- [29]. Based on the Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy model, Wang et al. [25] presented an adaptive fuzzy control scheme for a class of uncertain strictfeedback stochastic nonlinear systems with an unknown virtual control gain function. Psillakis and Alexandridis [26] proposed an adaptive neural network control scheme to deal with output tracking control for uncertain stochastic nonlinear strictfeedback systems with unknown covariance noise. In [27]- [29], neural network-based output-feedback adaptive control approaches were developed for a class of stochastic nonlinear strict-feedback systems. All the aforementioned results, however, required the unknown nonlinear functions to be in the affine forms, i.e., systems are characterized by input appearing linearly in the system state equation.

The pure-feedback nonlinear systems have a more representative form than strict-feedback systems. Moreover, many practical systems are in nonaffine structure, such as rolling mill systems, biochemical process, dynamic model in pendulum control, and so on [1], [30]. In pure-feedback nonlinear systems, no affine appearance of the state variables can be used as virtual control signals and actual control input, which makes the control design of pure-feedback systems quite difficult. Therefore, the control of nonaffine pure-feedback nonlinear systems is a meaningful and challenging issue and has received much attention in the control community in recent years [31]- [41]. By combining adaptive neural control and backstepping, in [31] and [32], a class of pure-feedback systems was investigated, which contained only partial nonaffine functions and at least has a control variable or virtual control signal in affine form. In [33], an "input-to-state stability modular" approach combined with the small-gain theorem was presented for adaptive neural control of completely nonaffine pure-feedback systems. Meanwhile, in [34], an adaptive neural network control based on the mean-value theorem was developed for pure-feedback nonlinear systems with disturbances. Afterward, many researchers further considered other kinds of nonlinear systems in nonaffine form, such as nonaffine pure-feedback systems with unknown control directions [36], with dead zone [39], and with time delay [41], nonaffine pure-feedback stochastic nonlinear systems [37], [38], discrete-time pure-feedback systems [40], and so on.

The control of nonlinear systems preceded by saturation nonlinearities has been an active topic since the saturation nonlinearities are common in many practical systems. It is difficult to control a system with saturation nonlinearities because the input saturation nonlinearity may severely degrade system performance and even lead to instability by giving rise to undesirable inaccuracy or oscillations [42]. Due to the nonsmooth property of saturation nonlinearities, traditional control methods are insufficient in dealing with the effects of unknown saturation nonlinearities. Therefore, the advanced control techniques to handle the effects of saturation have been called upon and have been studied for decades. In [43], model reference adaptive control was proposed for linear systems in the presence of magnitude constraints on the control input, where the plant poles lie entirely in the closed left half of the complex plane. In [44], an adaptive controller was applied to linear systems with magnitude saturation of the control input, where the adaptive controller is shown to result in global stability if the system is open loop stable and minimum phase and in local stability if otherwise. Correspondingly, the problem for controlling nonlinear systems with input saturation is an important topic in the control community and has attracted increasing attention in recent years [45]- [50]. In [46], a robust adaptive neural control approach is proposed for a class of multi-input and multi-output nonlinear systems with input nonlinearities. By introducing auxiliary design systems to analyze the effect of input constraints, Chen et al. [47] presented an adaptive tracking control scheme for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems with nonsymmetric input constraints, and the derived controller could guarantee that the closed-loop systems have semiglobal uniformly ultimately bounded stability. Wen et al. [48] considered the problem of adaptive control for uncertain nonlinear systems in the presence of symmetric input saturation and external disturbance, in which two new schemes were developed to compensate for the effects of the saturation nonlinearity and disturbance. However, the aforementioned results on control design for the systems with input saturation require that the control systems should be independent of stochastic disturbance.

Based on the aforementioned observation, in this paper, we consider the problem of output tracking for pure-feedback stochastic nonlinear systems with input saturation nonlinearity. Inspired by the work in [47] and [48], a novel adaptive fuzzy tracking controller is proposed for a class of nonaffine purefeedback stochastic nonlinear systems with nonsymmetric and unknown input saturation nonlinearity. The presented controller guarantees that all signals in the closed-loop system remain bounded in probability and the tracking error eventually converges to an arbitrarily small neighborhood around the origin in the sense of mean quartic value. The main contributions of this paper lie in the following: 1) The approximation-based adaptive control approach is extended to control stochastic purefeedback nonlinear systems in the presence of input saturation nonlinearity, and 2) to overcome the design difficulty from nonsmooth input saturation nonlinearity, i.e., sat(v), a smooth nonlinear function of the control input signal is used to approximate the saturation function with a bounded approximation error, i.e., sat(v) = g(v) + d(v) with d(v) = sat(v)g(v) being the bounded approximation error, and then, the mean-value theorem is applied to transform the nonaffine function into affine form, i.e., g(v) = g v μ v. Therefore, the proposed design approach does not require the prior knowledge of the bound of input saturation. In addition, only one adaptive parameter which is independent of the number of fuzzy rule bases needs to be estimated online for an nth-order stochastic nonlinear systems. As a result, the computational burden is significantly alleviated. This makes the proposed control scheme may be more suitable for practical applications.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The preliminaries and problem formulation are given in Section II. A novel adaptive fuzzy control scheme is presented in Section III.
The simulation examples are given in Section IV, followed by Section V which concludes this paper.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
div.p: Before presenting the main results, let us introduce some necessary definitions and lemmas. Consider the following stochastic system:
div.formula: dx = f (x)dt + h(x)dw, ∀x ∈ R n (1)
div.p: where x ∈ R n is the state of the system, w is an r-dimensional independent standard Brownian motion defined on the complete probability space (Ω, F, P ), and f (•) and h(•) are locally Lipschitz functions in x and satisfy f (0) = 0 and h(0) = 0, respectively. Definition 1: For any given V (x) ∈ C 2 , associated with the stochastic differential (1), define the differential operator L as follows:
div.formula: LV = ∂V ∂x f + 1 2 T r h T ∂ 2 V ∂x 2 h (2
div.p: where T r(A) is the trace of matrix A. Remark 1: As stated in [17], the term (1/2)T r{h T (∂ 2 V / ∂x 2 )h} is called the Itô correction term, in which the secondorder differential ∂ 2 V /∂x 2 makes the controller design much more difficult than that of the deterministic system.

Definition 2 [53]: The solution process {x(t), t ≥ 0} of stochastic system (1) is said to be bounded in probability if lim c→∞ sup 0≤t<∞ P { x(t) > c} = 0, where P {A} denotes the probability of event A.

Lemma 1 [26]: Consider the stochastic system (1). If there exists a positive definite radially unbounded twice continuously differentiable Lyapunov function V : R n → R and constants ν 0 > 0 and γ 0 ≥ 0 such that LV (x) ≤ -ν 0 V (x) + γ 0 then the following conditions hold: 1) The system has a unique solution almost surely, and 2) the system is bounded in probability.
Lemma 2 (Young's Inequality [12]): For ∀(x, y) ∈ R 2 , the following inequality holds:
div.formula: xy ≤ ε p p |x| p + 1 qε q |y| q
div.p: Lemma 3 [10]: Consider the dynamic system of the form
div.formula: θ(t) = -γ θ(t) + κρ(t) (3
div.p: where γ and κ are positive constants and ρ(t) is a positive function. Then, for any given bounded initial condition θ(t 0 ) ≥ 0, we have θ(t) ≥ 0 for ∀t ≥ t 0 .
In this paper, we consider a class of stochastic pure-feedback nonlinear systems as follows:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ dx i = f i (x i , x i+1 )dt + ψ T i (x i )dw, 1 ≤ i ≤ n -1 dx n = f n (x n , u)dt + ψ T n (x n )dw y = x 1 (4) where x = [x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x n ] T ∈ R n with xi = [x 1 , x 2 , . . . , x i ] T ∈ R i
div.p: and y ∈ R being the state vector and system output, respectively, w is an r-dimensional standard Brownian motion defined on the complete probability space (Ω, F, P ) with Ω being a sample space, F is a σ-field, and P is a probability measure. f i (.) : R i+1 → R and ψ i (.) : R i → R r (i = 1, 2, . . . , n) are unknown smooth nonlinear functions. u denotes the plant input subject to nonsymmetric saturation nonlinearity described by
div.formula: u = sat(v) = u max , v ≥ u max v, u min < v < u max u min , v ≤ u min (5)
div.p: where u max > 0 and u min < 0 are unknown constants of input saturation and v is the input signal of the saturation nonlinearity.

The control objective is to construct an adaptive fuzzy tracking controller v(t) for the systems (4) and ( 5) such that the system output y follows a desired reference signal y d in the sense of mean quartic value and all signals in the closed loop are bounded in probability.
According to the mean-value theorem [51], the functions 4) can be expressed as
div.formula: f i (•, •) in (
f i (x i , x i+1 ) = f i xi , x 0 i+a1 + g μ i x i+1 -x 0 i+a1 , 1 ≤ i ≤ n -1 f n (x n , u) = f n (x n , u 0 ) + g μ n (u -u 0 )(6)
div.p: where smooth function substituting ( 6) into (4) and choosing
div.formula: f i (•, •) is explicitly analyzed be- tween f i (x i , x i+1 ) and f i (x i , x 0 i+1 ), g μ i := g i (x i , x μ i ) = (∂f i (x i , x i+1 )/∂x i+1 )| x i+1 = x μ i , i = 1, 2, . . . , n, x n+1 = u, x μ i = μ i x i+1 + (1 -μ i )x 0 i+1 , 0 < μ i < 1. Furthermore, by
x 0 i+1 = 0, u 0 = 0, we have ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ dx i = (f i (x i , 0) + g μ i x i+1 ) dt + ψ T i (x i )dw, 1 ≤ i ≤ n -1 dx n = (f n (x n , 0) + g μ n u) dt + ψ T n (x n )dw y = x 1 .(7)
div.p: From ( 5), it can be seen that there exist two sharp corners if v = u max and v = u min . Therefore, the backstepping technique cannot be directly applied to construct the control input signal.
To solve this problem, similar to the method proposed in [48], a piecewise smooth function is used to approximate the saturation function and defined as
div.formula: g(v) = ⎧ ⎨ ⎩ u max * tanh v u max , v ≥ 0 u min * tanh v u min , v < 0 = ⎧ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎩ u max * e v umax -e -v/umax e v umax +e -v/umax , v ≥ 0, u min * e v u min -e -v/u min e v u min +e -v/u min , v < 0.(8)
div.p: Then, sat(v) in ( 5) can be expressed in the following form:
div.formula: u = sat(v) = g(v) + d(v) (9
div.p: where
div.formula: d(v) = sat(v) -g(v)
div.p: is a bounded function, and its bound can be obtained as
div.formula: |d(v)| = |sat(v) -g(v)| ≤ max {u max (1 -tanh(1)) , u min (tanh(1) -1)} = D. (10
div.p: Fig. 1 shows the approximation of the saturation function.
In addition, the mean-value theorem [51] implies that there exists a constant μ(0 < μ < 1) such that
where
div.formula: g v μ = (∂g(v)/∂v)| v=v μ and v μ = μv + (1 -μ)v 0 .
div.p: By choosing v 0 = 0, (11) can be written as
div.formula: g(v) = g v μ v. (12
div.p: Substituting ( 9) into (7) and using (12) result in ⎧ ⎨
div.formula: dx i = (f i (x i , 0) + g μ i x i+1 ) dt + ψ T i (x i )dw, 1 ≤ i ≤ n -1 dx n = f n (x n , 0) + g μ n g v μ v + d(v) dt + ψ T n (x n )dw y= x 1 . (13
div.p: To facilitate the control system design, the following assumptions are presented and will be used in the subsequent developments.
Assumption 1: The signs of g μ i , i = 1, 2, . . . , n, are known, and there exist unknown constants b m and b M such that, for
Apparently, g μ i is strictly either positive or negative. Without loss of generality, it is further assumed that
div.formula: 0 < b m ≤ g μ i ≤ b M .
div.p: Assumption 2: For the function g v μ in (11), there exists an unknown positive constant g m such that

Remark 2: The restriction in (15) was introduced in [48]. Since the actual control input signal v cannot be infinite in practice, this assumption is reasonable from a practical engineering point of view. Here, for the purpose of stability analysis, we still employ this inequality.
Remark 3: By means of Assumptions 1-2, it can be further assumed that
where b = min {b m , b m g m } is an unknown constant. Assumption 3: The reference signal y d (t) and its nth-order time derivatives are continuous and bounded.

On this note, fuzzy logic system will be used to approximate continuous function f (x) defined on some compact sets. Therefore, we adopt the singleton fuzzifier, the product inference, and the center-average defuzzifier to deduce the following fuzzy rules:
div.formula: R i : IF x 1 is F i 1 and x 2 is F i 2 and . . . and x n is F i n Then y is B i (i = 1, 2, . . . , N)
div.p: where x = [x 1 , . . . , x n ] T ∈ R n and y ∈ R are the input and output of the fuzzy system, respectively. F j i and B i are fuzzy sets in R. Since the strategy of singleton fuzzification, centeraverage defuzzification, and product inference is used, the output of the fuzzy system can be formulated as
div.formula: y(x) = N j=1 Wj n i=1 μ F j i (x i ) N j=1 n i=1 μ F j i (x i )
div.p: where Wj is the point at which fuzzy membership function μ B j ( Wj ) achieves its maximum value, which is assumed to be 1. Let
div.formula: s j (x) = ( n i=1 μ F j i (x i )/ N j=1 [ n i=1 μ F j i (x i )]), S(x) = [s 1 (x), . . . , s N (x)] T , and W = [ W1 , . . . , WN ] T .
div.p: Then, the fuzzy logic system can be rewritten as
div.formula: y(x) = W T S(x). (17
div.p: If all memberships are chosen as Gaussian functions, the following lemma holds.
Lemma 4 [52]: Let f (x) be a continuous function defined on a compact set Ω. Then, for any given constant ε > 0, there exists a fuzzy logic system (17) such that
div.formula: sup x∈Ω f (x) -W T S(x) ≤ ε.

div.head: III. ADAPTIVE FUZZY TRACKING CONTROL
div.p: In this section, a backstepping-based adaptive fuzzy control design procedure will be proposed, and during the design procedure, fuzzy logic system W T i S(Z i ) is used to approximate the packaged unknown function fi (Z i ) at Step i. The virtual control signal and the actual control input will be constructed in the following forms:
div.formula: α i (Z i ) = -k i + 3 4 z i - z 3 i 2a 2 i θS T i (Z i )S i (Z i ), 1 ≤ i ≤ n -1 (18) v(Z n ) = -k n + 3 4η 2 z n - z 3 n 2a 2 n θS T n (Z n )S n (Z n ) (19

div.formula: Z 1 = [x 1 , y d , ẏd ] T ∈ Ω Z 1 ⊂ R 3 , Z i = [x T i , θ, ȳ(i)T d ] T ∈ Ω Z i ⊂ R 2i+2 (i = 2, . . . , n),

div.head: Remark 4:
div.p: The adaptive law θ given in ( 22) is a function of all the error variables. Therefore, unlike the conventional approximation-based adaptive control schemes, the term 34) cannot be approximated directly by the fuzzy logic system W T i S i (Z i ). To solve this problem, in ( 40), (∂α i-1 /∂ θ) θ is divided into two parts. The first term on the right-hand side of ( 40) is contained in fi (Z i ) to be modeled by W T i S i (Z i ), and the last term in (40) which is a function of the latter error variables, namely, z j , j = i + 1, . . . , n, will be dealt with in the later design steps. This design idea will be repeated at the following steps.
div.formula: (∂α i-1 /∂ θ) θ in (
div.p: Step n. This is the final step. The actual controller v will be obtained. From (20) and the Itô formula, we have
div.formula: dz n = (f n (x n , 0) + g μ n g v μ v + d(v) -Lα n-1 )dt + ⎛ ⎝ ψ n - n-1 j=1 ∂α n-1 ∂x j ψ j ⎞ ⎠ T dw (47)
div.p: where Lα n-1 is given in (34) with i = n. Take the stochastic Lyapunov function as
By taking (46) with i = n -1 into account and using the completion of squares, the following result holds:

div.p: where 4 . So far, we can summarize our main result in the following theorem.

Theorem 1: Consider the closed-loop pure-feedback stochastic nonlinear system consisting of (4) and preceded by unknown input saturation nonlinearities (5), the controller (19), and the adaptive law (22). Under Assumptions 1-3 and given any initial conditions z j (0) and θ(0) belonging to Ω 0 (where Ω 0 is an appropriately chosen compact set), all the signals in the closed-loop system remain bounded in probability. Specifically, the error signals z j (j = 1, 2, . . . , n) and θ remain in a compact set Ω Z defined by
and eventually converge to the compact set Ω s defined by

Proof: For the stability analysis of the closed-loop system, choose the stochastic Lyapunov function as V = V n , and define ν 0 = min{4c j , γ, j = 1, 2, . . . , n} and γ 0 = n j=1 j . Then, (57) can be rewritten as
div.formula: LV ≤ -ν 0 V + γ 0 , t ≥ 0.
div.p: (60) IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON CYBERNETICS Furthermore, the following inequality can be obtained directly by [14,Th. 4.1]:
then, (61) satisfies
which means that

where V (0) = n j=1 (1/4)z 4 j (0) + (b/2λ) θ2 (0). By means of (63) and the definition of V , z j and θ are bounded in probability. Because θ is a constant, θ is also bounded. Since z 1 = x 1y d and y d is a bounded desired reference signal, it can be seen that x 1 is bounded in probability. α 1 is the function of z 1 and θ which are bounded variables; thus, x 2 = z 2 + α 1 is also bounded in probability. Similarly, it can be easily verified that x j (j = 3, . . . , n) is bounded in probability. Using (19), it is concluded that v is also bounded. Therefore, all the signals in the closed-loop systems remain bounded in probability. Furthermore, noting the definition of V = V n in ( 48) and (63), we can conclude that there does exist a compact set Ω Z defined in (58) such that the error signals z j and θ remain in it for all the time.
In addition, from (62), the following inequality holds:
As t → ∞, we have

Therefore, for j = 1, 2, . . . , n, the error signals z j and θ eventually converge to the compact set Ω s defined in (59), i.e., all the signals in the closed-loop system are uniformly ultimately bounded in probability.

Remark 5: Note that the saturation function ( 5) contain two sharp corners if v = u max and v = u min in which sat(v) is not smooth. Therefore, backstepping cannot be directly used to design the control input signal. To overcome the difficulty, a piecewise smooth function g(v) in ( 9) is utilized to approximate the saturation function with a bounded error d(v). However, the approximation function g(v) is of nonaffine form with respect to control signal v, which makes it hard to directly design the controller. Then, the mean-value theorem is applied to transform the nonaffine function into affine form, i.e., g(v) = g v μ v, which is easily used to design the controller. In addition, the Itô correction term, such as (3/2)z 2 1 ψ T 1 ψ 1 in (25), cannot be directly included in the function f1 , making the control design difficult. Then, the completion of squares is used to overcome this difficulty, which can be seen in ( 25). This idea is repeatedly applied in each step.

Remark 6: It should be pointed out that similar results have been obtained in [29], [39], and [47]. The main differences between our result and the ones in [29], [39], and [47] are as follows: 1) From the controlled systems, the results are obtained in [39] and [47] for deterministic systems and in [29] for the strict-feedback stochastic system without input saturation, and in this paper, we considered a class of purefeedback stochastic nonlinear systems with input saturation, which is in a more general form; 2) compared with the result in [47], a different approach (see Remark 5) is used to overcome the design difficulty from nonsmooth input saturation function sat(v); and 3) θ = max{( W * i 2 /b), i = 1, 2, . . . , n} is used as the estimated parameter in this paper, so only one adaptive law is required to update online for nth order systems, which is suitable for higher order nonlinear systems.

div.head: IV. SIMULATION EXAMPLES
div.p: Example 1: To illustrate the effectiveness of our result, consider the following third-order pure-feedback stochastic nonlinear system with input saturation:

where x 1 , x 2 , and x 3 denote the state variables, y is the system output, u denotes the output of the saturation nonlinearity defined in (5), and the nonsymmetric input saturation limits are chosen as u max = 5 and u min = -6, respectively. It is apparent that the system satisfies Assumptions 1-2. The control objective is to design an adaptive fuzzy control scheme such that all the signals remain bounded and the system output y follows the desired reference signal y d = 0.5(sin(t) + sin(0.5t)). To construct the fuzzy controller, the fuzzy membership functions are chosen as follows:
According to Theorem 1, the virtual control input signal and the actual control input are defined as with the adaption law as follows:
div.formula: α i = -k i + 3 4 z i - 1 2a 2 i z 3 i θS T i (Z i )S i (Z i ), i = 1, 2 v = -k 3 + 3 4η 2 z 3 - 1 2a 2 3 z 3 3 θS T 3 (Z 3 )S 3 (Z 3 )
θ = 3 i=1 λ 2a 2 i z 6 i S T i (Z i )S i (Z i ) -γ θ where z 1 = x 1 -y d , z 2 = x 2 -α 1 , z 3 = x 3 -α 2 , Z 1 = [x 1 , y d , ẏd ] T , Z 2 = [x T 2 , θ, ȳ(2)T d ] T ,and
T d ] T .
div.p: In the simulation, the design parameters are taken as follows:

and η = 1. The simulation is run with the initial conditions [x 1 (0), x 2 (0), x 3 (0)] T = [0.1, 0.1, 0.1] T , and θ(0) = 0. The simulation results are shown by Figs. 23456. Fig. 2 shows the system output y and the reference signal y d . From Fig. 2, we can see that the desired tracking performance has been achieved. Fig. 3 displays that the state variables x 2 and x 3 are bounded. Figs. 4 and5 show the signals v and u, respectively. Fig. 6 shows that the adaptive parameter θ is bounded. where the term δ(x 1 , x 2 ) denotes unmodeled nonlinearity, w is the stochastic disturbance, f 1 (x 1 ) and f 2 (x 1 , x 2 ) are uncertain nonlinear functions, u is the output of the saturation nonlinearity defined in (5), and the saturation limits are chosen as u max = 8 and u min = -6, respectively.

In the simulation, choose δ(x 1 , x 2 ) = (1/3)x 3 2 , f 1 (x 1 ) = 0.1 sin x 2 1 , and f 2 (x 1 , x 2 ) = 0.3x 2 cos x 1 , and choose the fuzzy membership functions defined in Example 1 and the reference signal y d = 3 + sin t + 0.5 sin(0.5t). It is assumed that x 1 = 0 as in [54]. According to Theorem 1, the virtual control input signal α 1 , the actual control input v, and the adaptive law θ are defined in (18) Remark 7: Note that the stochastic disturbance and input saturation nonlinearity are considered in the aforementioned examples simultaneously. Theoretically, the control methods proposed in [31], [32], [47], and [48] cannot be applied to solve the control problem of the more general systems (66) and (68). In addition, the proposed control scheme in this paper is simpler, which is more suitable for controlling high-order systems in practical applications.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, an approximation-based adaptive fuzzy control approach has been proposed for a class of nonaffine purefeedback stochastic nonlinear systems in the presence of unknown input saturation nonlinearity. The proposed controller guarantees that all signals in the closed-loop system remain bounded in probability and the tracking error converges to an arbitrarily small neighborhood around the origin in the sense of mean quartic value. Numerical results further demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme.

figure.head: Example 2 :
figure.figDesc: To show the applicability of the proposed control scheme, consider the following Brusselator model in dimensionless form[54]:⎧ ⎨ ⎩ ẋ1 = C -(D + 1)x 1 + x 2 1 x 2 ẋ2 = Dx 1 + (2 + cos(x 1 )) ux 2 1 x 2 y = x 1 (67)where x 1 and x 2 denote the concentrations of the reaction intermediates and C, D > 0 are parameters which describe the supply of "reservoir" chemicals. The following statement was given in[54]: "As a simplified model depicting chemical reactions, the Brusselator model is derived from partial differential equations after a series of approximations. Thus, there must exist modeling errors and other types of unknown nonlinearities in the practical chemical reactions." In addition, as a practical chemical reaction, the existences of stochastic disturbance and input saturation are inevitable in the Brusselator model. Therefore, the controlled Brusselator model is assumed as⎧ ⎨ ⎩ dx 1 = C -(D+1)x 1 +x 2 1 x 2 +δ(x 1 , x 2 )+f 1 (x 1 )dw dx 2 = Dx 1 +(2+cos(x 1 )) u-x 2 1 x 2 +f 2 (x 1 , x 2 )dw y = x 1 (68)

with i = 1, (19), and (22) with n = 2, respectively. The simulation is carried out with the system parameters C = 1 and D = 3, the initial condition [x 1 (0), x 2 (0), θ(0)] T = [3.2, 1, 0] T , and the design parameters k 1 = k 2 = 8, a 1 = a 2 = 5, γ = 0.06, and λ = 1. Figs. 7-11 show the simulation results.

analytic.title: He was an Assistant Professor with Saint Mary's University, Halifax, from 1993 to 1995, and with Dalhousie University, Halifax, from 1995 to 1998. He joined Lakehead University in 1998. His research interests include vibration control, control of nonlinear systems, and mechatronics. Dr. Liu is a member of Professional Engineers Ontario

monogr.title: 1982, the M.A. degree in mathematics from the Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China, in 1991, and the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering from Northeastern University
2003 and the M.Sc. degree in mathematics from Inner Mongolia University

respStmt.orgName: Huanqing Wang received the B.Sc. degree in mathematics from Bohai University ; D. degree in the Institute of Complexity Science, Qingdao University ; Institute of Complexity Science, Qingdao University ; Department of Electrical Engineering, Lakehead University ; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Lakehead University ; Research Associate with the Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong ; Research Fellow with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, National University of Singapore ; Professor with the Institute of Complexity Science, Qingdao University

biblStruct.note: respectively, and the Ph.D. in electrical and electronic engineering from the Nanyang Technological University. He has published more than 60 research papers and coauthored two monographs. His current research interests are mainly in systems analysis and control, robust control, and fuzzy control
